title: Maria Grazia Puxeddu, Ph.D.
text:
Currently in the job market for a faculty position!!
I’m a postdoc at the University of Rome La Sapienza, working in network neuroscience.
My research is interdisciplinary, at the intersection between neuroscience, network science, and complex systems. I’m primarily interested in how the brain’s anatomical architecture constrains its functional repertoire, as well as how brain networks evolve over time or across individuals in response to factors such as cognitive load, development, aging, or disease.
But there’s a lot more! If you’re interested in these lines of research feel free to reach out!

title: About
text: Hello! Here follows a brief presentation of my academic path and interests.

title: About
text:
Academic trajectory
I earned my Ph.D. in Bioengineering in February 2020 under the supervision of dr. Laura Astolfi at the University of Rome La Sapienza. In those years I mostly focused on studying methods and concepts of network science and validating them on brain networks.
I recently completed a postdoc at Indiana University Bloomington, working with dr. Olaf Sporns. This postdoc was lined up to start right after graduation, but the pandemic hit (UGH!), so I had to wait a while before officially moving to the USA. Eventually, I made it! During my postdoc, I initiated several lines of research: I explored the relationship between brain topology, brain volume, and brain phylogeny in an extensive mammalian dataset; I investigated the relationship between the brain’s structural and functional architectures through the lens of network modularity and network communication; I put my hands on a non-human, non-MRI-based, complete (!) connectome and inferred how its topology underpins neurobiology at the cellular level. Last but not least, I incorporated Network Control Theory and Information Theory into my suite of analytic tools to investigate brain networks!
Throughout my training, I had the opportunity to investigate lifespan data, establishing age-related trends in the reorganization of the human connectome. I also focused on identifying subject-specific features of brain topological organization and hope to link these findings to cognitive functions and behavior in future research.

title: About
text:
Research interests
Moving forward, I want to leverage my interdisciplinary background to address foundamental questions in neuroscience, such as: how does the anatomical architecture inform the functional connectivity? How does brain architecture reorganize over short timescales to enable cognition, or longer timescales to adapt to changes over the lifespan? Can we use such relationships to find biomarkers of neurodegenerative diseases?
Since last March I am back to Rome, but I am on the job market for a faculty position! Check out my Github and my google scholar if you’re curious about my work, and feel free to reach out!
